awd_titl_txt: MRI: Development of a High-Speed Light-Sheet Light-Field Microscope for Imaging in Materials Sciences, Physics, and Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Description:
Optical microscopy provides an essential window into the micrometer scale structure and dynamics of diverse systems ranging from simple colloidal suspension and biological cells to tissues and entire developing organisms. Most optical microscopy studies are limited to two-dimensional regions of interest. A typical method of characterizing three-dimensional structure relies on confocal point scanning techniques, which are very slow. Due to lack of appropriate techniques, high-spatial resolution imaging of fast dynamics of macro-sized samples remains uncharted territory. This project paves the way for overcoming this barrier. The resulting novel imaging technique named light-field light-sheet microscopy is tested and optimized with diverse samples ranging from quantifying dynamics and topological structure of three-dimensional active liquid crystals to imaging the whole-brain of a fruit fly during food-search. The design principles of the microscopy and the associated software analysis code are shared with scientific community. The imaging technique is also popularized through its inclusion in the Annual Santa Barbara Summer School in Quantitative Biology, where the participants receive the training in using the instrument. 

Technical Description:
By seamlessly merging the existing techniques of the multi-view selective plane illumination microscopy and the light-field microscopy, scientists are developing a new optical microscope capable of imaging millimeter-sized samples with isotropic point spread function. When compared to the fastest imaging times accessible to state-of-the-art selective plane illumination microscopes, the technique being developed increases the temporal resolution by almost two orders of magnitude. This opens up the possibility of three-dimensional, high-spatial-resolution imaging of macroscopic samples at frequencies as high as 5 Hz. The microscope is used to study a variety of samples that range from materials science, cell biology and neuroscience. In particular, scientist use the microscope to (1) elucidate the interplay between the topological structure and dynamics of motile disclination loops in three-dimensional active nematic liquid crystals, (2) quantify temporal propagation of strain deformations in active gels where stresses are generated by single molecular motors, (3) perform whole-brain imaging during food-search in D. melanogaster larvae, and (4) characterize a whole nervous system as it forms and activates in the embryogenesis of D. melanogaster.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project has established a new high speed volumetric imaging instrument that enables new research in soft and living matter physics. The instrument is based on an emerging live microscopy technique called light sheet microscopy. Light sheet microscopy generates optical sections by illuminating the sample with a two dimensional sheet of light. This sheet is used to excite genetically encoded fluorescent proteins, such as the green fluorescent protein (GFP). An objective focused on this light sheet captures light emitted from the excited GFP. In this way, a two dimensional section through a sample is mapped onto a camera, and computationally stored. This method is non-invasive, allowing the monitoring of living sample for long time. By motorized repositioning of the sample, volumetric images are acquired. Typically, these volumetric images are limited to tens of seconds for extended specimen.

 

This project has brought high speed volumetric modficiations, and thereby a substantial speedup to light sheet microscopy. The new features allow us to acquired ultra-high-speed 3D images of samples. In this way we are able to address new scientific problems that could not be studied before. The research enabled by this instrument spans from investigating the dynamics of novel materials such as 3D active nematics relevant to 3D maps of activity in the nervous system of developing embryos, and live visualization of input output functions computed during conflict of interest experiments conducted in behaving animals. 

 

The instrument that has been enabled through this funding mechanism has been successfully applied to two research problems. First, in the realm of soft matter phyiscs, we have visualized the dynamics of three-dimensional active nematic liquid crystals and the associated active isotropic fluid. Using the newly available features and the enhanced capabilities of the light sheet microscope we have acquired ultra-high-speed 3D images of such samples. In this way we where able for the first time to conclusively demonstrate presence of a surface-induced nematic alignment layer and the associated active anchoring. Second, in the realm of living animals, we have faithfully live visualized nervous system activity across an entire freely behaving fruit fly larva. The data obtained from these two case studies open up new opportunities in research, an provide valuable preliminary results for future projects.
